item.title: Marvel Rivals Is Out Now And You Can Get Free Iron Man Skin If Youâ€™re Quick To Play It
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/marvel-rivals-is-out-now-and-you-can-get-free-iron-man-skin-if-youre-quick-to-play-it/1100-6528275/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Marvel Rivals has officially arrived, and the hero shooter is launching with 33 Marvel characters to start, with surely more to come in the future. But for players who are ready to dive into this free-to-play game, NetEase has a special Iron Man skin waiting for free.

Tony Stark's Iron Man: Armor Model 42 first appeared in the comics in 2012. and a live-action version of it debuted in Iron Man 3. To get your hands on that armor skin in Marvel Rivals, players need to click the settings icon and then hit the bundle code button. From there, just enter the code nwarh4k3xqy any time before March 3, 2025, and you'll be good to go.

In the current Steam charts, Marvel Rivals has landed at No. 2 just behind Counter-Strike 2, and it's rising quickly. The first month will be Season 0, and it comes with 8 maps for Quick Match and Competitive modes, as well as a Conquest map, and a new Practice Range.

Additionally, NetEase is encouraging players to watch their favorite Twitch streamers play Marvel Rivals because there will be Twitch Drops throughout Season 0 where players can earn in-game rewards simply by being present for those online sessions.

The Twitch Drops rewards from Season 0 are listed below:

December 6-31

  • Watch 30 minutes: Magneto [Will of Galacta] Spray
  • Watch 1 hour: Magneto [Will of Galacta] Nameplate
  • Watch 2 hours: Magneto [Cosmic Collapse] Emotes
  • Watch 4 hours: Magneto [Will of Galacta] Costume

December 20-29

  • Watch 1 hour: [Winter Stockings] Spray

Earlier this month, NetEase explained how Marvel Rivals will handle its monetized systems. Only cosmetics will be for sale, via free currency or Latice, the game's premium currency. Players will be able to purchase costumes for their heroes, as well as MVP animations, emotes, and more. For more intel, check out GameSpot's guide to everything we know about Marvel Rivals.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Fatal Fury's Mai Shiranui Shows Off Her Moves In Street Fighter 6 Teaser
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/fatal-furys-mai-shiranui-shows-off-her-moves-in-street-fighter-6-teaser/1100-6528272/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

In 2019, Fatal Fury's Mai Shiranui was one of the most-requested fighters for Nintendo's Super Smash Bros. Ultimate. She was excluded from the game because "Super Smash Bros. Ultimate is for good boys and girls of many different ages," according to Smash Bros. creator Masahiro Sakurai. However, Mai is on the way to Street Fighter 6 early next year, and she's starring in a new teaser trailer that shows off her fighting style.

Amusingly, Mai calls herself "a good girl" in the video while inviting a novice fighter to her Fatal Fury 2 stage for some fighting tips. And it isn't long before their training session is interrupted by some rude ninjas who are out to get Mai for some reason. Those shinobi picked the wrong woman to mess with, as she gracefully dispatches them with precision.

Mai was actually a guest character in the zombie survival mobile game Doomsday: Last Survivors earlier this year, but Street Fighter 6 will be her first confrontation with the Capcom characters since SNK vs. Capcom: SVC Chaos in 2003. Mai's fellow Fatal Fury hero, Terry Bogard, was added to Street Fighter 6 earlier this year.

Terry and Mai will also be reunited in Fatal Fury: City Of The Wolves, the first sequel in the series to arrive in the last 25 years. In addition to the standard fighting game matches, City of the Wolves will also feature a solo-player RPG mode when it hits Xbox Series X|S, PlayStation 5, and PC on April 25, 2025.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: How Stalker 2's Launch (Literally) Broke The Internet
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/how-stalker-2s-launch-literally-broke-the-internet/1100-6528270/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Stalker 2: Heart of Chornoby has enjoyed a generally positive overall reception, despite launching with a few issues. But Stalker 2 released to near-unanimous praise from players in Ukraine, the country in which the game is set and the homeland of its developers. In fact, Ukrainian players were so eager to get their hands on GSC Game World's latest entry in the Stalker series that the game's launch quite literally broke the internet.

Ukrainian players flocked to the game as soon as it launched, resulting in nationwide internet outages in the hours after its release, GSC creative director and executive producer Mariia Grygorovych said in a recent interview.

"It's a bad thing because the Internet is important, but at the same time it's like, 'Whoa!'" Grygorovych said of Ukrainian players' enthusiasm for the game. "It touched everyone in the country."

Grygorovych and the rest of the development team at GSC dealt with some truly harrowing experiences during the creation of Stalker 2, including a fire at GSC's studio caused by Russian shelling, and the death of colleague Volodymyr Yezhov, who lost his life fighting Russian forces. Russia's invasion of Ukraine added an enormous amount of strain on the studio and its developers, some of whom ultimately made the difficult choice to leave their home country to continue working on the game in safety. Currently, GSC Game World's staff is split between two locations: an office in Prague, and one in Kiev.

The complicated (and often heartbreaking) story of Stalker 2's development is detailed in a documentary created by its developers. Entitled War Game: The Making of Stalker 2, the film documents the immense hurdles GSC devs faced as they fought to finish the sequel to the iconic Stalker: Shadow of Chernobyl. But Stalker 2 was a labor of love, and Grygorovych says the sacrifices were worth it.

"For us and our team, what's most important is [that] for some people in Ukraine, they feel a little bit happier [now] than they were before [Stalker 2's] release," Grygorovych said of the game's significance in Ukraine. "We did something for our home country, something good for them."

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
